Class JsonFileOperations

java.lang.Object
com.education.ztu.game.JsonFileOperations
public class JsonFileOperations extends Object
Utility class for file-based JSON serialization and deserialization.

This class provides convenient methods to persist Java objects to JSON files and load them back from disk. It serves as a high-level wrapper around the JsonParser class, handling file I/O operations automatically.

Key Features:

  • Object to File: Serialize objects to JSON files
  • File to Object: Deserialize JSON files to typed Java objects
  • Automatic Conversion: Uses JsonParser for JSON conversion
  • Error Handling: Comprehensive exception handling and logging
  • File I/O: Uses modern NIO methods (Files class) for efficiency

Supported Types:

Any type supported by JsonParser can be saved and loaded:

  • All Participant types: Schoolar, Student, Employee
  • Team classes with generic type parameters
  • Custom objects with Gson support

Usage Examples:

// Save a student to a JSON file
Student student = new Student("Alice", 20);
JsonFileOperations.saveToJsonFile(student, "student.json");
// Creates file with JSON content:
// {
//   "name": "Alice",
//   "age": 20,
//   "tempInfo": "Temporary data for Alice"
// }

// Load student back from file
Student loadedStudent = JsonFileOperations.loadFromJsonFile(
    "student.json", Student.class
);
System.out.println(loadedStudent.getName()); // Output: Alice

// Save a team to a file
Team team = new Teaminvalid input: '<'>("Eagles");
team.addNewParticipant(new Student("Bob", 21));
JsonFileOperations.saveToJsonFile(team, "team.json");

// Load team back from file
Team loadedTeam = JsonFileOperations.loadFromJsonFile(
    "team.json", Team.class
);
System.out.println(loadedTeam.getName()); // Output: Eagles

File Encoding:

All files are read and written using UTF-8 encoding by default.

Error Handling:

Both methods wrap IOException in RuntimeException to provide an unchecked exception that can be handled at a higher level. All errors are logged with full details before being thrown.

Performance Notes:

  • Uses Files for efficient file I/O
  • Suitable for small to medium-sized files
  • For very large files, consider streaming approaches
Since:
2024

  • Method Details

    • saveToJsonFile

      public static void saveToJsonFile(Object object, String filePath)
      Saves an object as JSON to a file on disk.

      This method:

      • Converts the object to JSON using JsonParser.toJson(Object)
      • Writes the JSON string to a file at the specified path
      • Creates the file if it doesn't exist
      • Overwrites the file if it already exists
      • Logs the operation at info and debug levels

      Example:

      Student student = new Student("Charlie", 22);
JsonFileOperations.saveToJsonFile(student, "data/students/charlie.json");

      Exception Behavior:

      If the save operation fails (e.g., file permissions, parent directory doesn't exist), an error is logged and a RuntimeException is thrown.

      Parameters:
      object - the object to save to a JSON file (must not be null)
      filePath - the file path where the JSON will be saved (must not be null) Can be relative (e.g., "file.json") or absolute path
      Throws:
      RuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs during file writing
      NullPointerException - if object or filePath is null
      See Also:
      • loadFromJsonFile(String, Class)
      • JsonParser.toJson(Object)
      • invalid reference 
        java.nio.file.Files#write(java.nio.file.Path, byte[])

    • loadFromJsonFile

      public static <T> T loadFromJsonFile(String filePath, Class<T> clazz)
      Loads an object from a JSON file on disk.

      This method:

      • Reads the JSON content from the specified file
      • Deserializes it to the specified class using JsonParser.fromJson(String, Class)
      • Returns the deserialized object
      • Logs the operation at info and debug levels

      Example:

      Student loadedStudent = JsonFileOperations.loadFromJsonFile(
    "data/students/charlie.json", Student.class
);
System.out.println(loadedStudent.getName());

      Type Parameter:

      The clazz parameter determines the type of object returned. This must match the JSON structure in the file for proper deserialization.

      Exception Behavior:

      If the load operation fails (e.g., file not found, invalid JSON), an error is logged and a RuntimeException is thrown.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type parameter matching the clazz parameter
      Parameters:
      filePath - the file path to load from (must not be null) Can be relative (e.g., "file.json") or absolute path
      clazz - the Class to deserialize the JSON into
      Returns:
      a new instance of class T populated from the file's JSON data
      Throws:
      RuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs during file reading or if JSON deserialization fails
      NullPointerException - if filePath or clazz is null
      See Also:
      • saveToJsonFile(Object, String)
      • JsonParser.fromJson(String, Class)
      • Files.readString(java.nio.file.Path)
